39818327.review:
Als erstes vorrab, Ich selbst habe (noch) kein eigenes VR Headset (deswegen auch die 0,1Std Spielzeit nur bei mir die hier angezeigt werden), habe aber einige Std bei meinen Bruder mit dessen HTC Vive gespielt.

Ziemlich witziger Wave Shooter in Comic look.

Wie der Name schon sagt, kriegt man es hier mit Zombies zu tun, Pappzombies! Und zwar massig davon!!!

Man selber steht die ganze Zeit in unterschiedlichen Leveln an einen Fleck (man braucht also nicht sehr viel Platz) und man muss außer sich mal umdrehen und ducken um bsp. Sachen aufzuheben, nicht groß vom Platz wegbewegen. (Moiten Sickness sollte da also nicht so schnell auftauchen)
Anfangs stehen einem noch kleine Waffen zu Verfügung, mit ner bestimmten Anzahl an Zombie Kills gibt es dann neue Waffen wie Schrotgewehr oder Ak-47 usw. die Freigeschaltet werden können. 
Dazu gibt es noch auf nen kleinen Tisch der direkt hinter einen steht nen paar nützliche Items zu finden, wie Granaten, Fleisch und Radio (beide zum Ablenken der Zombies) Gasflasche usw.. mit denen sich die Horde der Zombies besser bekämpfen lässt. Bei Sachen die geworfen werden kann es schonmal vorkommen das man die höhe der Decke unterschätzt, wer also beim zocken ne Lampe oder was anders über sich hängen hat, sollte mit seinen Wurfarm also vorsichtig sein, sonst haut man evtl in der hektik des Spiels mal dagegen, das ist aber nen typisches VR Problem wenn man am falschen Platz spielt :D

Für Leute die schon immer mal wissen wollten ob sie ihre Pistole wie Lucky Luke schneller als ihr eigenen Schatten ziehen können, gibt es noch kleine Extragames mit Global Highscore (der auch in normalen Spiel vorhanden ist)zur Auswahl, wo man dann mit ner Pistole oder ner anderen Waffe z.b. 3 Ziele so schnell wie möglich killen muss.(kann man bei Pappzombies eigentlich von killen reden? ^^). Wen man das dann unter 1,5sek schafft mit Zielen die in 3 unterschiedlichen Richtungen stehen, kommt man sich schon bissle wie Clint Eastwood oder Charles Bronson vor :D
Manche in der Liste scheinen wirklich schneller als Lucky Luke zu sein (Nein kein cheat oder Bug oder so, sie sind einfach sauschnell^^ )

Auf jeden Fall einer der besseren Waveshooter, wo man immermal zwischendurch für nen paar Runden reinschnuppern kann um nen paar Pappkameraden in die Ewigkeit zu schicken. :)

34088367.review:
Pappkameraden killen bis die Fetzen fliegen.
Zombie Training Simulator ist ein Waveshooter der vieles richtig macht.
Die Grafik ist im Comikstil gehalten und wirkt sehr passend, alles läuft flüssig. (GTX970, i5)
Wie immer ist es Ziel des Spiels so lange wie möglich zu überleben. Dafür steht einem ein freispielbares Waffenarsenal zur Verfügung. 
Wärend man am Anfang noch verzweifelt mit einerAutomatik versucht die anrückenden Zombiehorden zurückzuschlagen, ballert man im späteren Verlauf noch mit Schrotflinten, Maschinengewehren oder auch beidem gleichzeitig auf die Pappkameraden (ja richtig gelesen, die Zombies werden durch Pappatrappen dargestellt) und gibt ihnen mit Granaten und explodierenden Fässern den Rest.
Der Nahkampf anhand eines Schwertes auf dem Rücken ist zwar auch möglich, aber nicht zu Empfehlen.
Das Waffenhandling ist zwar nicht realistisch, fühlt sich aber gut an.
Zusätzlich zur reinen Feuerkraft stehen einem noch Ablenkungsmanöver zur Verfügung. Zum einen kann man sie mit Fleisch weglocken, zum anderen mit krach, anhand eines Radios.
Neben dem reinen Überlebensmodus auf verschiedenen Karten gibt es noch ein paar Herausforderungen, z.B. 4 Zombies so schnell wie möglich erschießen.
Natürlich gibt es auch eine Highscore/Bestenliste, um sich mit anderen zu messen.
Ich habe das Spiel zu meiner Vive erhalten, würde aber auch den Vollpreis zahlen, nachdem ich es kenne.

Gruß
Ziffi

33547047.review: My favorite for gun mechanics.  This is basically a target range shooter or a wave shooter depending on which mode you play.  You basically just shoot paper zombie targets but in one mode they will advance on your position and you can use all sorts of novelty items like lanterns and grenades to take them out.  You even get a katana.  That's pretty freaking cool.  You can even alter the grip angle so if you are a 1911 guy you don't have to adapt to shooting a Glock (that will make sense to the people it was inteded for).  Loads of fun and easy to grasp the concept of.  It's been a hit among my friends when they come over to play.  It's a lot easier for first time VR users than some of the more elaborate games and I still keep coming back to it for workng on pistol skills.  If you are looking for a serious wave shooter or FPS then you'd be better off with Sairento, Onward, or Overkill VR.  If you want to shoot targets, I like this over Lethal VR.

When you feel like causing great destruction to a hell of a lot of zombies at the same time, this is exactly what you're looking for!

Here's a bit of game play from my experience: https://youtu.be/_nFjnBKCKVs 

This game is what it would be like if a comic, card boarded horde of zombies was to come for you. Fear not, as you have guns and explosives to fight them off! With little items for distracting them,  a catchy Strummin' tune, you quite quickly work up a sweat blasting wave after wave! There's a good variety in what weapons you can use, from duel welding a shotgun and pistol to having a fully automatic Desert Eagle with a 250 round clip! You can choose from several places to fight the horde with each giving you the opportunity to apply a unique strategy. In saying that, I would like to have more interaction with the environment. There are different zombies with their own characteristics that will attack keeping you on your toes. If you don't pay attention that will eat you!
Zombie Training Simulator has a cartoon theme which makes playing the game a light hearted, fun and incredibly satisfying experience for all!

30909472.review:
I got this one for free and that's about as much as I would ever pay for it. Maybe it's worth $5. It's just all around meh. This is really a VR game for casual gamers, and if you consider yourself anything other than that, don't buy this. There are better VR experiences to spend your money.

It's just ridiculously repetitive and easy. There's no deep strategizing here: throw some steak, shoot. Throw a grenade every now and then. It gets intense, but not in anyway that feels rewarding when you make it through. Contrast this with Space Pirate Trainer, and it's just a night and day difference in how rewarding the gameplay is. Everytime I clear a wave in SPT I feel like a hero, when I clear a wave in this game, I'm like "meh...I did the same thing I did for the other waves."

The small amounts of progression mechanics are nice, but there's not really much. Unlock a gun. Wooo. Then do the same thing with the gun as you've done with the other guns...

The graphics are interesting, I can understand why they went for the cardboard cutouts since its more accessible to more people who don't want all the gore. But it makes the zombies feel a bit too lifeless for me.

Conclusion:
Casual gamers, spend $5 on this and no more. You might enjoy it.
Anyone else, buy something else.

30893342.review:
TL;DR - Zombie Training Simulator is well built solid VR game that allows you to challenge friends to small skill tests. Well worth the time with small progression.

Zombie Training Simulator is game of skill training. It is a game that doesn't require you to do much. No fancy dodging, or technical aspects. This is about aiming and shooting! This means practicing your aim to get headshots, as zombies only die from headshots. But fret not! There is a variety of weapons and explosive at your disposal! This means that you have small goals to get to. With these weapons unlocking with kills across all your sessions you can go practice and play their survival games or skill tests and feel like you're accomlishing something. I have unlocked all the guns and each one have fun little differences to them. The final weapons are good fun to enjoy, but the early guns are also good to train with for other games. The survival games each have different maps, routes for the zombies to use and more or less supplies to use. The steaks allow you to survive longer and leads to a bit of chaos as learning when they get finished to throw out another leads to excitement when the zombies all turn and start charging you again.

Overall this is a great game that I enjoy and is well worth the price. The asthetic is nice and charming by having the zombies without much of a "scare" factor. It is a great game for quick fun and testing your reflexes!

29288217.review:
Note: I received Zombie Training Simulator as a bonus with my HTC Vive purchase.  It wasn't exactly free, but it was included in the price of the headset.

[h1]One of the best introductory wave shooters for VR.[/h1]

Wave shooters are one of the most common genres in the VR economy of games, but they can be some of the most fun you'll have with roomscale VR.  Zombie Training Simulator is no exception.

Zombie Training Simulator starts you in a sudo-main menu with a limited choice of weapons and a few not-so-aggressive zombies.  The zombies are like cardboard cutouts, which is possibly a reminder that a lot of us got ourselves introduced to the possibilities of VR with Google Cardboard... and that's also where the title of the game comes from, I guess.

You'll unlock more weapons as you kill zombies and rack up your kill count.  Your kill count gets higher, your access to weapons becomes less limited.  You get a basic pistol to start.  You also get a katana, which is located on your back.  You will most likely rack up the zombie kill count slowly at first, but it gradually gets more fast-paced.  You quickly unlock a better pistol that unfortunately has less ammo.  You later get dual-wielded versions of the same pistols.  You also get grenades, shotguns, and some other weapons.

The ultimate goal is to get higher on the leaderboards for each game mode and each level.  This will be difficult because a vast majority of the Vive owners got this game with their Vive.  Those who did not, well, I feel that the game's worth a purchase, anyway.  It's a lot of fun, and I can't recommend it enough to people who really want a fun wave shooter.

[h1]How does Zombie Training Simulator compare to Space Pirate Trainer?[/h1]

Space Pirate Trainer is cool and possibly more fun in some ways, but Zombie Training Simulator offers a better feeling of progression thanks to its weapon unlocks and additional meta-games.  Zombie Training Simulator sports a more child-friendly, simplified graphical style which makes it easier to render tons of objects on the screen.  Space Pirate Trainer looks amazingly realistic despite the lack of arms.  My recommendation is to get both games if you can, but you should consider Zombie Training Simulator better for holding your attention for a long period of time.

Yet once you strap yourself into a VR unit, the experience is very visceral.  My only real complaint is the game feels grindy for the experience.  I would have liked a more diverse weapon selection.   Overall, this may be one of the better first generation VR games.

This game surprised me with it being the one I kept coming back to over all the other typical highly recommended titles. I got this bundled with my Vive and I'm damn happy it was! I would still easily recommend this at full price.

Despite being a wave shooter, it's very fun, competitive with leaderboards, skill tests and unlockable guns keep the replay value.

+ Great visuals
+ Weapons to unlock over time
+ Very competitive skill modes with leaderboards kept me for hours at one point trying to enter to the top 10 times
+ leaderboards are for each gun and day / night time which keeps it fresh
+ Really fun game concept with throwing the meat, grenade and canisters. 
+ Challenging enough at first, then becoming competitive
+ Good selection of levels
+ Night time (hardcore) option is simple, but adds a new experience

- After around wave 35 I experience horrendous lag where it puts me back to the Vive home screen while carrying on the game, this is obviously a big issue when going for high scores. Others have reported it being around wave 80 they hit the lag. HOWEVER, this only seems to happen with the dual red pistols. 

Overall, definitely recommend it and a good game to show new VR users what it's all about :)

28529806.review:
I forgot to check the box when first writing the review, but I did receive this game for free with my Vive. Would've paid for it though.

This game is excellent for VR. A Wave Shooter game with various weapon types and modifiers (grenades, propane tanks, steaks to attract zombies, etc.) that also has "skill tests" and free-form play. I would highly recommend this game to anyone that can play it. I've had zero issues with performance (6700K @4.7 ghz + GTX 980).

PROs:
- wide variety of guns
- increasing difficulty with different "maps" and waves
- creativity with types of zombies and the effects they have
- there's always a katana strapped to your back for last ditch efforts (that's saved me a few times)
- the music is fun to listen to (I love "Strummin' ") and I kinda dance while holding dual pistols
- there's a "hardcore" mode where you play at night. Instead of being able to see all the zombies, you have to shine your flashlight (attached to each weapon) to see them, so always check behind you.

CONs:
- the sound is too loud by default, so turn it down
- some of the weapons take a long time to unlock (end game guns are 50,000 kills, I'm at 14,000 kills after a couple hours, but I haven't found a way to increase my kill rate)
- would love even higher difficulty in terms of number of zombies rather than being in the dark

28212571.review:
I have had the chance to receive and play a copy of ZTS and I absolutely fell in love with it.
The concept is truly simplistic but that’s the beauty of this game!
It is a wave shooter unlike others in this genre with a zombie theme. 

Graphics: 

The visual fidelity of this game is quite simple but it works together in harmony in such a nice way that you get immersed immediately. Having the zombies be cutouts and various scene objects in 3D, it creates a very good depth effect. The scenery is excellent from the choice of levels you have to choose from, my favorite being the forest, the colors are vivid and jump in your face, zombies are modeled very nice and have a sharp look to them and overall, my system did not experience any hiccups so optimization is good with this one.

Gameplay:

You start out by having different game modes such as skill challenges, survival and so on with a pistol to start you off with. Since this is a wave shooter, zombie hordes come at you from different directions with a chance of a massive horde spawning, keeps the game fresh. What sets this apart from another wave shooter is the adrenaline this gives you as at certain times, the screen could be overfilled with zombies and you rush and scramble to reload that gun or find that piece of meat to throw, only to find out you are all out and you must melee them in order to survive the best you could. It is truly a fun experience.

Sound:

Sound is basic but hits the right cues. Zombies make noises and bi-direction sounds seems to work very well with my surround sound headset. I do enjoy the background music as it adds to the game well.

Overall:

Having received this product for testing, and considering its current price point of $20, I would recommend anyone who owns a vive to give this game a go. It will suck you in and make you keep going due to its fun atmosphere, intuitive but simple upgrade system, and well-polished shooting mechanics. I would love to see further future updates as by following the previous ones, they have slowly dwindled down but you can’t ask for more since this is a wave shooter, and a good one.

26187720.review:
This game has a lot going for it, in my opinion. First it can act as a great intro shooter on the Vive, as you have the "safehouse" to practice shooting targets, throwing grenades and other items, and playing with different guns. Secondly, it has skill challenges where you complete said challenges to move up leaderboards, my personal favorite being Crow's Foot. Finally, survival mode where you fight off waves of enemies until you are overwhelmed (and leaning back in real life to give yourself precious inches between you and the oncoming zombies).

I am having trouble finding any cons for this game, other than generic "lack of multiplayer" or "lack or realism" complaints, but that is not what this game is trying to be. It is just a great game with smooth gameplay and solid a feel.

In fairness, I did receive this game for free with my Vive, but I could absolutely see myself dropping $20 on it.

26181977.review:
The game's main gameplay, shooting, is very bland for a VR title, and of the free games given with the Vive, this one I've probably seen enough of despite playing the least. 

All weapons are one handed, reloading is non-interactive and you can't use anything akimbo. I guess the positive aspect is that this is a way to introduce people that would be afraid of normal zombie or "scary" games to VR, but after other VR titles like Raw Data, Brookhaven and Hover Junkers, this leaves a lot to be desired. After a few minutes I felt like I got the jist of it: fire at heads, throw explosives/shoot explosives, reload. The different guns, without actual gunplay mentioned above, just feel like stat differences considering.

There are a few modes, like "challenges", but they don't really have a lot to offer for someone like me. The shooting just feels so bland to begin with that I don't really have any reason to stick around and try out more.

I would pass on this and get something else in the $20 range. If you literally just want to shoot at targets, I'd get Hotdogs, Horseshoes and Handgrenades instead, as the weapons are very interesting to use and have more interactivity.

For more VR reviews, check out the rest on my Steam Curator page:
http://store.steampowered.com/curator/31930555-Auburoks-VR-Reviews/

26118511.review:
I love this game. For $20, you cannot go wrong with buying this. There are great choices for both survival modes and skill based modes, and a sizeable choice of weapons. You actually unlock these weapons by doing something great: killing zombies. The guns feel accurate in how they operate, and look great.

The graphical and design choices for this game work very well. At first I wondered about how I felt when looking at the screenshots, but the cartoonish appearance makes the game very fun and lighthearted, yet I still find myself in a brief panic when a large horde of zed run at me and I haven't any grenades. The less-realistic graphics also make the game kid-friendly and good for those who aren't a huge fan or horror games or similar. 

There are a few music tracks that can be played on the in game radio, and they add a nice effect to the game. The sounds are really great, and while the zombies may look friendly, they make all sorts of traditional zombie games. 

I would suggest this game for anyone looking for a Vive shooter, I personally have found myself playing it more than other games I own.

This is pretty cool, and has some neat ideas and mechanics, but I'm glad I got it with the content bundle.

If you like wave shooters, this is a polished one with some nice crowd-control-based gameplay, lots of guns to choose from, and some neat minigames and such. If you like zombie games, this is a kid-friendly one with a "hardcore/night mode" that actually manages to be somewhat more tense as well.

It's a super well-rounded, well-executed game, but the core gunplay isn't all that interesting. It's mostly aiming at a bunch of zombie heads, most of which are at the exact same height, and right next to each other. As I said, the real mechanics are in the crowd control and resource management mechanics.

It's a good game, and it held my interest for a good while, but I'm not sure I'd have payed $20 for it. Still, glad to have it.

23908315.review:
"BWAINS!!" *Grumble* *GRRB* *GURK* *GRAK* 
*BANG* *BANG* *BOOM* *EXPLOSION* *PEW* 

Zombie Training Simulator is exactly what it sounds like; Its a preparation for the IRL zombie apocalypse - except with a twist: Its a ton of fun! The graphics are simplistic, yet detailed and polished. Although they are not realistic, the game is still highly immersive. Because the zombies are cardboard cut-outs, the game allows you to enjoy the same fun that a bloody, gory, zombie, shooter game gives you, without all the blood, guts, and horror (Although it can be very startling when you turn around and see a zombie you were not expecting to be there, #CardboardJumpscare). 

ZTS includes quite a large variety of weapons including many different gun types, along with a katana you can pull out from behind your back. This allows you to continue to fight off the zombies while your gun auto-reloads. Each gun is unlocked by killing a certain total number of zombies. You start off with a pistol, and can eventually end yourself up with 2 SMGs (one in each hand). There is also gas cans and grenades you can throw, to explode a group of zombies. Steak is also available to you. You can use this to slow down the zombies and bait them to a specific area.

The replayability level of this game is very high. This is due to the addictive gameplay that ZTS offers. Killing as many zombies as you can to unlock more weapons is very heart pumping and a ton of fun. Trying to get to a greater wave then your previous record is also very addictive, as is attempting to get higher up on the leaderboard to take over that #1 spot. The many different maps, environments, and difficulties, are also main reasons why this game does not get old. 

If you are in any way interested in arcade, shooter style, games, I greatly recommend picking up Zombie Training Simulator. I'm sure you will enjoy it! 

NOTE: I do get occasional framerate drops and jittering with my GTX980. Its not enough to ruin the gameplay in any way,  but it is noticeable when I use the explosives or there are a ton of zombies that are gathered in one area.

This is our go-to shooter.   

Others are more realistic, or more frightening.   Still others are more frantic, or have more bells and whistles.

This, on the other hand, is a beautiful, relaxing, tacictical shooter and area-management game.

Use steaks to draw the attention of the targets.   Use gas cans and grenades to wipe out entire packs.  

Upgrade your weapons, and suddenly the gameplay takes a giant shift as you explore what double handguns, shotguns, and even automatic weapons can offer.

The wooden-target feel of the zombies is perfect for enjoying the game of live-shooting area-control without becoming overly-distracting.    But rest assured, when the final zerg-rush happens, as it inevitably must, these wooden horrors will get you!

Others might be explorations of shooters and shooter mechanics.

This is an area-control shooting game.   Elegant game mechanics, seamless VR interface, immersive experience.    Lose yourself playing this game!

Brilliant.

Support this artist!

Zombie Training Simulator ist eine actiongeladene irrwitzige VR-Erfahrung. Von seinem Stand aus schießt man auf Wellen von sich nähernden Zombies, wirft mit Granaten, explosiven Fässern, Benzinkanistern und Fleisch um sich um die untoten Horden zu vernichten oder wegzulocken. Das Gameplay ist dabei so actiongeladen, dass man bereits nach 15 Minuten schweißgebadet und außer Atem ist. Ein hervorragendes, spaßiges Workout.

Die Grafik ist schön und vor allem die Waffenmodelle wissen zu gefallen und sind sehr detailliert. Der Sound der Schießeisen klingt fett.

Es gibt den klassischen Survival Modus, wo man Welle um Welle abwehrt, bis man stirbt und es gibt diverse Skilltests, wo man so schnell wie möglich eine vorgegebene Anzahl Zombies mit verschiedenen Waffen killen muss. Es gibt eine globale Rangliste und eine Freundes-Rangliste um seinen Skill zu vergleichen.

Sieben verschiedene Waffen sorgen für Abwechslung.

Dies ist eines der Vive-Spiele, die ich immer wieder gerne spiele. Eine klare Kaufempfehlung für Shooter-Freunde.

Fun and addictive.  Many others reviewers have covered the various nuances  of the game so I thought I would provide a "Can I play it?" Informational.   (Synopsis at end for those looking for the short and sweet, so to speak.)

I am 6'6" and have just enough room in my game den to pretty much stand in the center and spin around with my arms stretched out.  That should have been enough space to meet the minum for a 'room' setup, however Vive claims it's not, so I ended up setting it up as as standing-only setup.  This game claims you need a 2m x 1.5m play area, but I figured I would give it a shot and if it didn't work I could refund the game.

Turns out 'standing only' works just fine!  The table was right next to me and I was able to reach everything with no issues.  A wheelchair-bound buddy of mine was also able to play this game just fine, as he could still see over the table while seated.

TL:DR - This game is also playable if you have a 'standing only' Vive setup.

22945020.review:
https://youtu.be/8wcaPA2nk3g

Zombie Training Simulator may sound like the most generic VR title so far, joining the ranks of Zombie games, simulator games and Trainer games currently in the SteamVR lineup, but what you get with ZTS is far from generic.

ZTS is packed full of content. Your standard mode is a wave survival style game, you pick a weapon at the start of a game and stick with it for as long as possible. You are always postitioned next to a table containing various supplies to help you fight off the undead hoards including steaks which can be thrown to distract the zombies who will gather around the hunk of meat until it is completely consumed, these are essential to survival as the sheer number of zombies on-screen would overwhelm you if not for this element of control. You also have grenades which explode after a set time when you throw them and shootable explosives like propane bottles and jerry cans which can make you feel like a complete badass if you shoot them in the air.

The graphics are simple but effective, the idea of the game is to simulate training yourself for the zombie apocalypse, so you aren't fighting real zombies, but instead some very stylised cardboard cutout zombies, these can only be killed with a headshot meaning that this game is more about precision and strategy than wildly firing at the hoards. The survival mode has multiple maps of various difficulties, zombies will have different paths and items on your table will vary from level to level.

The challenges are all about defeating a set number of zombies in the fastest time possible, Crow's foot is all about precision, eliminating four zombies from both sides in the fastest time possible, where as Zombie bowling has a huge hoard lined up like bowling pins, armed with one grenade and your gun of choice, you have to clear the whole lot in the quickest time you can.

If you feel yourself getting too well aquanted with the game and want to ramp things up a little, you can switch to night time mode, you gun will have a flashlight on it and this will be the only way you will be able to see, it really changes the gameplay and puts you even more on your toes as it's not as easy to know where the zombies will be coming from.

With a variety of weapons which can be gradually unlocked by killing a specified number of zombies which can be used across each gameplay type, each with their own leaderboards, there is a lot here to keep you coming back. You get a lot of value from the game and it's easily one of my favourite Vive experiences so far.

22766604.review:
*Disclaimer* I was provided this game for review honest review purposes. 

Zombie Training Simulator lies to you ...

It pretends because the zombies are cardboard cut-out cartoon zombies that you won’t freak out when they are closing in on you as you desperately to reload your weapon. Damn lies...

It isn’t the visuals that freak you out – it’s the sound.

Packed with a multitude of modes for you to play around with, something for everyone, ZTS is an excellent early game for the Vive that is worth every penny of the asking price. A great deal of time and effort has obviously gone into polishing this game and it shows. The graphics are bright and colourful, without being confusing. The zombies actually feel like they are made out of cardboard, shooting chunks off them is satisfying and gives you a great sense of real damage.

You start with access to limited weapons, a pistol as I recall, and are rewarded with more and better guns as you kill more zombies. It’s a little frustrating that you can’t use all the guns right away but it does give the game a natural progression which might be missing otherwise.

Some gallery shooters on the vive have weapons that feel like toys, and this makes those games feel very lightweight. ZTS’s guns feel great, the animations are believable without being overcomplicated and the use of the feedback in the controllers is good. You can almost feel the bullets smack into the zoms. 

The use of explosives is also excellently handled. Grenades, petrol cans and lanterns can be used to wipe out large concentrations of zombies. Getting the Z’s to stand in one place is managed by clever use of handy meat chunks you can lob out into the range.

On top of all this the leader board system is excellent. Showing your rank amongst friends or worldwide.

I love this game. Well done devs.

22659915.review:
Zombie Training Simulator is an addicting wave-based survival shooter. Gunplay is solid with no complaints. I am a huge fan of the cartoon pseudo 2d theme. It creates an atmosphere the is enganging, but, not tense and draining such as a more horror themed survival shooter such as The Brookhaven Experiment. The cartoony theme and low level violence makes this game suitable for older children. The difficulty settings provide a suitable challenge for any skill ranges. In addition to wave-based survival there is also skill based challenges which test the player's ability to cope with a specific circumstance. The progression system and gunplay make this title enjoyable and something you will keep coming back to for quite a while.

Gameplay Breakdown:
Choose from one of the guns on the table and select your challenge. In Survival, you use the resources on your table and explosives littered around the map to make it to the end of the wave. Meat acts as a zombie magnet. Propane tanks and gas cans are throwable explosives that need to be shot. Grenades are throw-and-forget timed explosives. The objective in the skill challenges varies from one to the next.

Pros:
+Cartoony theme is enjoyable and suitable for older children.
+Intense zombie gameplay without a tense atmosphere.
+Multiple maps and skill challenges.
+Progression system to unlock bigger and badder guns.
+Throwable resources and littered explosives respawn at the end of the round.
+Difficulty settings make this title accessible for any player regardless of skill level.
+Theming is great for people who want to shoot massive amounts of zombies but not have to deal with a scary or dramatically tense atmoshpere.

Cons:
-The weapon system is a bit disappointing in that you can't have both the traditional primary (assault rifle, smg, shotgun) and secondary (pistol) at one time. Because of this there is almost never a reason to use the pistols once you unlock better weapons because they are straight inferior. Being able to swap to your secondary instead of reloading would fix this, and, greatly improve gameplay.
-The strategy for survival seems pretty systematic. Throw meat to distract the zombies. Throw explosives into large groups if there isn't one littered nearby. Shoot at zombie heads. Throw more meat when the previous one's duration expires.
-After completion of a skill challenge there is no incentive to replay beyond trying to beat your time.
-Progression system seems to be a bit of a grind.
-Unlocking new guns is only achievable through total zombie kills. Pretty boring, as they could have instead rewarded by beating a certain amount of waves on a map or a certain time/score in a skill challenge.
-I don't know how much additional content is going to be added post-launch.

All in all I feel that this title was still worth the $20.

Don't be fooled by the cartoony style - this game is intense.

I would definitely recommend getting this game, it's a charming wave shooter that isn't just barebones.

The main meat of the game is in the survival modes, and facing giant hordes while managing distractions and explosives is really cool. You can get hundreds to thousands of kills in a good survival session and it really gives the feel of mowing down a horde. What makes this game different to a barebones wave shooter like space pirate trainer is the progression system, the gamemodes, and the different maps. 

Unlocking new guns sets a good goal and pushes you to play just a little bit more to try out the next gun, and I'm always  looking forward to the next unlock. Night time mode is also great, and it kind of gives the same feeling I get in the Brookhaven experiment demo - although this has a lot more to do right now and runs a lot better.

Shooting feels really good in this game, and my bullets are always going where I feel like they should go. Some other games don't have the gunplay feeling as right, but it feels really good here and you can really hone your accuracy.  

The zombies looking like cutouts is a really good thing for the game - landing shots has a lot of visual feedback, and the simple look of the zombies means you can have hordes of hundreds on screen at once. 

In terms of performance, it is really good as a result of the cartoon style, which also looks great. The game runs really well. I am getting 90fps and running the game butter smooth even on my old 7950, which is below the minimum spec. Giant hordes and explosions don't seem to make a difference.  

While the game is already great, it would be awesome if the devs added more maps, and more guns. I would love some akimbo/duel wield gun unlocks too as most of the game you are just doing nothing with your non-shooting hand save for the occasional grenade/meat throw. However, the game is still awesome and very easy to get into for showing your friends, and I'd say quite worth the price for the amount of time you can get out of it.

22507676.review:
I bought this thinking I might refund it if it didn't seem worth the money, but it turned out to be surprisingly fun. Also helped me improve my aim in other games with less-frequent shooting.

The survival modes tend to involve mowing down literally hundreds of zombies in a wave, which can get to feel like overkill at times, requiring constantly mashing the trigger, but there's some strategy involved in using explosives etc. I spent the most time trying to improve my scores in the various skill modes. Guns reload automatically rather than requiring any complex motions, but that's necessary due to the constant streams of zombies.

One major drawback: No dual wielding of any weapons. The only thing your second hand is useful for is throwing grenades and other objects, and most of the time you'd be better using both hands on one controller. They should really allow at least akimbo pistols, even if it was a bonus mode without a scoreboard. Hopefully they'll consider it in an update.

Really like it! I've gotta say, it's not just "another zombie game", it feels like a lot of thought was put into this one. 

Survival mode is pretty intense, especially in some of the harder levels. It's all about managing your resources (distractions & explosives). You have to set some stuff up beforehand and then figure out just the right times to use the rest. 

And even though survival is fun, I actually prefer the skills levels. Each one has a very specific predetermined layout, and is essentially a time trial. They feel like puzzles where you have to come up with a plan to kill all the zombies as fast as possible. 

Definitely one of the most fun and replayable Vive games I've played yet.

I played about 2 hours on the first night.  The guns feel very satisfying to shoot.  It is pretty fun to fight your way out when you're surrounded by ten zombies right in your face.
